message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The most important recommendation to prevent SIDS is to have the baby sleep in supine position. Sleeping with the parent or cardiorespiratory monitoring may not necessarily prevent SIDS. Smoking around the baby increases the risk of SIDS.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The most important recommendation to prevent sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS) is to have the baby sleep in supine position as studies have shown that it decreases the risk of SIDS. Sharing a bed with a parent increases the risk of SIDS. Avoiding second-hand smoke exposure also helps to reduce the risk, but it is not the most important recommendation. Cardiorespiratory monitoring of the baby at home is not necessary for prevention of SIDS.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The most important recommendation to prevent SIDS is to have the baby sleep in supine position. Sleeping with the parent or monitoring the baby’s cardiorespiratory activity may not necessarily prevent SIDS, while smoking around the baby increases the risk of SIDS.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The most important recommendation to prevent SIDS is to have the baby sleep in supine position, as this has been shown to significantly decrease the risk of SIDS. Sleeping with the parent or monitoring the baby at home does not prevent SIDS. Avoiding exposure to smoke is also important for overall health, but does not specifically prevent SIDS.

We refer to online resources on pediatrics for help. The most important recommendation to prevent SIDS is to have the baby sleep in the supine position. The other options are not recommended as sleeping with a parent or using home monitoring devices have not been shown to decrease the incidence of SIDS, and exposure to smoke is a risk factor for SIDS.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The most important recommendation in preventing SIDS is having the baby sleep in the supine position. Other measures that can help reduce the risk include avoiding bed-sharing, avoiding overheating, using a firm sleep surface, and avoiding exposure to smoke. Cardiorespiratory monitoring may be recommended in certain high-risk situations, but it is not the most important recommendation in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The most important recommendation to prevent SIDS is to have the baby sleep in the supine position. Co-sleeping with the parent is not recommended as it increases the risk of accidental suffocation. It is also important to make sure that no one smokes around the baby, but this is not the most important recommendation. Cardiorespiratory monitoring at home is not routinely recommended for healthy infants.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The most important recommendation to prevent SIDS is to have the baby sleep in the supine position. Other recommendations include a firm sleep surface, avoiding overheating, and breastfeeding. Sleeping with the parent or cardiorespiratory monitoring are not recommended prevention strategies. Smoking around the baby should also be avoided as it is a risk factor for SIDS.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The most important recommendation to prevent SIDS is to place the baby in the supine position during sleep. Sleeping with the parent and cardiorespiratory monitoring are not proven to prevent SIDS, while exposure to tobacco smoke is a risk factor for SIDS.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The most important recommendation to prevent SIDS is to have the baby sleep in supine position. Sleeping with the parent increases the risk of suffocation and overheating, and while making sure that no one smokes around the baby is important, it is not the most important recommendation to prevent SIDS. Cardiorespiratory monitoring of the baby at home is not a routine recommendation for prevention of SIDS.
